name: vscode-dotnet-runtime
author: Microsoft Corporation
description: This extension installs and manages different versions of the .NET SDK and Runtime.

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_installSdk
languageModelTools.userDescription: Installs a .NET SDK system-wide for building and running .NET projects
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Installs a .NET SDK GLOBALLY/system-wide using official installers: MSI on Windows, PKG on macOS, or package managers on Linux (apt for Ubuntu/Debian, yum/dnf for Fedora/RHEL - only these distros officially supported). BEFORE calling: Check if project has a global.json file - if so, use the version from sdk.version field. The SDK INCLUDES runtimes (same major.minor), so installing SDK 8.0.x also installs runtime 8.0.y. Requires admin/sudo. Goes in Program Files (Windows), /usr/local/share/dotnet (macOS), or /usr/share/dotnet (Linux) and IS on PATH. Version can be major (8), major.minor (8.0), feature band (8.0.1xx), or fully qualified (8.0.201). If no version provided and no global.json, uses the recommended version from Microsoft's release API.

version.description: The .NET SDK version to install. Examples: '8', '8.0', '8.0.1xx', '8.0.201'. If not provided, the recommended version from Microsoft will be used. Check global.json in project first!

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_listVersions
languageModelTools.userDescription: Lists available .NET SDK and Runtime versions that can be installed
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Lists available .NET SDK or Runtime versions from Microsoft. Use this to help users choose which version to install. Returns version numbers, support phase (active, maintenance, eol), and whether it's an LTS release. Recommend 'active' support versions for best experience.

listRuntimes.description: If true, lists runtime versions. If false or omitted, lists SDK versions.

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_findPath
languageModelTools.userDescription: Finds the path to a .NET installation that meets specified requirements
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Finds an existing .NET installation path (dotnet executable) that meets the specified version and architecture requirements. Use this to check if .NET is already installed or to find which dotnet executable VS Code extensions (C#, C# DevKit) are using. Search priority: (1) existingDotnetPath VS Code setting, (2) PATH environment variable, (3) DOTNET_ROOT env var, (4) extension-managed local installs. NOTE: Extension-managed local installs are NOT on PATH and NOT visible via 'dotnet --version' in terminal.

version.description: The minimum .NET version required (major.minor format, e.g., '8.0')

mode.description: Whether to find an SDK or runtime installation. Defaults to 'runtime'.

architecture.description: The CPU architecture. Defaults to the current system architecture.

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_uninstall
languageModelTools.userDescription: Uninstalls a .NET SDK or Runtime version
languageModelTools.modelDescription: Uninstalls .NET. IMPORTANT: The uninstall list ONLY shows extension-managed LOCAL installs by default. TRICK: If user wants to uninstall a GLOBAL SDK (like from C:/Program Files) that's not in the list, first use installDotNetSdk with the SAME version - it will detect it exists and REGISTER it, then it will appear in uninstall list. Global SDK uninstalls require admin privileges. Call without parameters to show interactive picker.

mode.description: Whether to uninstall an SDK or runtime

global.description: If true, uninstalls a global/system-wide installation. If false, uninstalls a VS Code-managed local installation.

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_getSettingsInfo
languageModelTools.userDescription: Get comprehensive information about .NET Install Tool settings, installation types, and troubleshooting
languageModelTools.modelDescription: CALL THIS TOOL FIRST when users ask about .NET installation issues, settings, or configuration. Returns comprehensive guide including: (1) existingDotnetPath setting - controls which .NET extensions USE internally, NOT what user's code runs on, (2) difference between local extension-managed installs vs global/admin SDK installs, (3) why extension installs are NOT on PATH and NOT visible via 'dotnet --list-sdks', (4) how to see what's installed, (5) TRICK: to uninstall a global SDK not in the list, first 'install' same version to register it then uninstall, (6) common misconceptions and troubleshooting scenarios.

languageModelTools.name: dotnet-install-tool_listInstalledVersions
languageModelTools.userDescription: Lists .NET SDK or Runtime versions that are currently installed on the system
languageModelTools.modelDescription: USE THIS TOOL INSTEAD of running 'dotnet --list-sdks', 'dotnet --list-runtimes', 'dotnet --info', or 'dotnet --version' in terminal. This tool does NOT require user permission and provides the same information. By DEFAULT (no mode specified), returns BOTH SDKs AND Runtimes - equivalent to 'dotnet --info'. DO NOT run dotnet terminal commands after calling this tool - the result is complete and authoritative. Set mode='sdk' for only SDKs, mode='runtime' for only runtimes.

dotnetPath.description: Optional path to a specific dotnet executable to query. If not provided, uses the dotnet on PATH (global install). Example: 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe'

mode.description: If omitted, returns BOTH SDKs and Runtimes. Set to 'sdk' for only SDKs, 'runtime' for only runtimes.

dotnetAcquisitionExtension.existingDotne.markdownDescription:
The path to an existing .NET host executable for an extension's code to run under, not for your project to run under.
Restart VS Code to apply changes.

‚ö†Ô∏è This is NOT the .NET Runtime that your project will use to run. Extensions such as `C#`, `C# DevKit`, and more have components written in .NET. This .NET PATH is the `dotnet.exe` that these extensions will use to run their code, not your code.

Using a path value in which .NET does not meet the requirements of a specific extension will cause that extension to fail.

üöÄ The version of .NET that is used for your project is determined by the .NET host, or dotnet.exe. The .NET host picks a runtime based on your project. To use a specific version of .NET for your project, install the .NET SDK using the `.NET Install Tool - Install SDK System-Wide` command, install .NET manually using [our instructions](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download), or edit your PATH environment variable to point to a `dotnet.exe` that has an `/sdk/` folder with only one SDK.
